segments.text: Yeah, sure. Between 2017 and 2019 I tried to launch different projects and small startups. While enrolled at university I studied economics. Then I worked for different companies as a full time employee, as an analyst role. My main goal has always been to start something from scratch, my own project or my own business and work for something that was bigger than the tradition traditional 9 to 5 job. I've always used these projects to escape from the 9 to 5 and try to reach something different.

segments.speaker: B

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: Yeah, sure. So the build and sell challenge was really simple. You needed to launch, validate and sell micro business in 30 days. The first product was pitch 2.0 pitch deck generator. I worked only for 45 days on this project, I made $300 and then we decided to sell it for 2,500. I thought, this is the challenge, this is the fast execution. You can apply, you know, to the products. So let's try to do the same. The same, the same, month after month. Then the second product we launched was One Tap AI. OneTap AI was, I would say, very simple EXC formula generator. So you just needed to type in plain English what you want to do on Excel. And the tool was going to give, you know, the exact formula to use in your spreadsheet. In this case, we made like almost $7,000 and we sold it for almost 25k dollars after 3 months. Then we launched your coverletter.com and we sold it for 7k after 40 days. Very interesting product because you could generate a cover letter based on the job application. Then we worked on recapturegpt.com, an AI summarizer. So basically you could summarize whatever you want. YouTube videos, presentation, docs. And we sold it for 34k of dollars after six months. Then we had tweetsbot IO. So basically you could generate tweets based on a doc or on a website. Was not so successful. We made 1k and we sold it after 3 months for 5k. The last product was AiwebDesigner IO. You could generate a landing page by just prompting. We made 1.2k and we sold it after three months for 12k in that case. And then we got Softgen AI. Softgen AI was the first AI by coding apps and we grew it from 20k to half million error. And then we sold it after three months.

segments.speaker: B

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: Yeah, sure. So the first step is, of course, you need to set your goals. Do you want to sell it in three months, six months or more? So this is important because it defines, of course, your product roadmap development, your needs, and how fast you need to go. Start with, of course, defining what you want to do with your product. The step two is the validation stage. I usually validated product by using a single landing page builder named. Yep. So my only goal was, you know, to distribute the landing page on my X channel, collect emails from interested people and use the building public strategy. I usually consider like a 15% conversion rate on my landing page as a good buff. Then we have the step three, which is the building stage. So once it's validated, I can start building the Product with I call it the feedback loop approach. So in this case you need to build one key feature. You need to send the product link to the first batch of users who left the emails on the landing page you built. You can ask the feedback and based on that you can improve, improve the product and relaunch it. So it's going to be, you know, a sort of loop of build, feedback, edit and rebuild feedback, edit. The step four, of course, is the growth. So you need to grow your product. One key strategy here I've always applied to the organic growth has been the building public strategy, as mentioned before. And then the last step is the selling stage. You need to package, you know, the business as an asset someone else can run. The most important thing buyers want to know are error growth margins, average revenue per use, lifetime value, customer acquisition, cost, churn rate. So these are all key values and you should always work on getting the best as possible here.
